We were comparing this unit to an older very similar model X-Acto we have. It is faster (the motor is stronger) and quieter than the older similar model we bought a couple of years ago. The point that is put on the pencils exposes slightly more wood which is good if you tend to hold the pencil by the exposed wood. It also has a nice amount of heft to it that means you don't have to hold it while you are sharpening--it will stay in place even as you push pencils in.However the cup is really disappointing. It is shallow and makes a mess when it is pulled out. We had filled the cup with shavings after only sharpening about 10 pencils. Also the accumulated static electricity made the wood shavings jump around and get on everything. So while the motor is heavy duty and the point it makes is pretty good the cup for the shavings is way too shallow for a 'heavy duty' machine. I contrast it to the Stanley Bostitch EPS12HC SuperPro 6 which has a cup at least 10 times the size of this X-Acto.However the Bostich doesn't put as nice a point on pencils. So if you are sharpening only a very small amount then the emptying of the cup won't be as big an issue for you and there is a good chance you'll like the point this machine makes.

Four school-aged kids sharpen a lot of pencils. This model did a great job for a few hundred sharpenings but ultimately stopped working after just a few months. I can't be sure what made it broke (there is a fair chance of foul play from the kids) but I didn't find anything jammed in there. In my opinion these need to be built to withstand normal wear and tear from kids and this one didn't last long enough to feel good about.

I have tested out quite a few pencil sharpeners in the past few years in a high use office environment.There is nothing quite like several people using a sharpener all day to really see its quality and performance.This X-Acto Deluxe has thus far been a bit of a disappointment. It looks like a quality item. However the point it puts on the pencil is not very good compared to another X-Acto we have. Furthermore sometimes it doesn't put a point at all. Finally the pencil savings cup is one of the smallest I have seen. Honestly for a product priced and positioned as a Premium Sharpener the size of the shavings cup is somewhat laughable.The X-ACTO Teacher Pro (1675) sharpener I have had vastly superior results with it features a large cup and costs less.Unless I received a bad unit I just can't recommend this over other sharpeners. Even if I got a bad unit it doesn't excuse the insane small shavings cup an area that the Teacher Pro model excels at.

I wanted to like the 'X-Acto 1645 Deluxe Heavy-Duty Electric Pencil Sharpener' more than I did.To be sure it does what it needs to do - puts a fine point on a pencil a third quicker than most. Plus it's hefty weighing in at 2 pounds 5 ounces on my kitchen scale; and at only 4' wide by 4' high by 6' deep it feels dense and sturdy. But as I sharpen only a few times a day 'heavy duty' isn't something I can attest to so I'll fall back on the wisdom of Jurassic Park... Gennaro

The sharpener itself is fine but the screws are total junk. Two of the three screws broke while screwing them into the wood they are just not made with very good metal. My advice is to use a set of good screws you have laying around the house just to be safe.

Carol Adrienne is a pretty good writer. I was interested in her life story but I couldn't particularly relate to it. I wanted more actual ideas and theory and things I could do to help me and less focus on her story. Some of the activities were thought provoking and rewarding. She also had some good resources listed in the footnotes. No bibliography however which was frustrating. A bibliography would've made it faster to find the particular resources that I was looking for in terms of my future reading. I think that people who enjoyed the Celestine Prophecy (which I haven't read) may like this book. It wasn't particularly what I was looking for although it wasn't awful by any means.
Its simply a dynamite for conquering any desired job

An interesting topic with some very interesting ideas. But there is a lot of repetition -- where was the editor? -- and the prose is slow and slack. I would have prefered a more detached clinical approach to the one taken -- tell a dramtic tale but poorly and then discuss the theories.A 75 page monograph disguised as book. But the content is indeed of interest.

[...] The book is a good primer on fudamental and technical analysis but that is about it. I suppose that my expectations were too high. I subscribe to the website spin-off of thestreet.com and find the commentary reporting and trading tips well worth the money. This is the sort of hard hitting writing that I expected in the book. My opinion save your money on the book and just use the website daily.

I was looking for something a bit more adept -- this is 'investing for dummies' -- which has its place but the title makes it look like it has some new ideas when in fact it's mostly advice you've read on thestreet.com and elsewhere in one book. Valuable to a novice a nice but unnecessary compendium for more experienced investors. While this book wasn't what I was looking for I also think the rips on Cramer and thestreet.com are unwarranted and childish and the reviews based on those criticisms are off the mark.

'It truly is a brave new world for investors' writes Dave Kansas at the conclusion of this book. The phrase 'brave new world' comes from Shakespeare via Aldous Huxley who of course used it ironically. It will be the rare investor who can read those words today without a twinge of pain

If you are looking for a biography of Queen Elizabeth II don't bother with this book which is little more than rambling reminiscences of some of the Queen's experiences. Poorly written - one jumps from one topic to another without any sense of continuity and there are annoying grammatical flaws - the book focuses rather narrowly on the author's experiences as a journalist covering certain royal tours. Rather shockingly she also uses unwarranted and inappropriately derogatory adjectives to describe certain people. Anecdotes are fun the photos are nice but this book could have been much better. Review is based on the hardback edition.

this is the first time that i have used the one-click method of making a purchase.and i have been waiting for about thirty minutes for confirmation via-e-mail.is it my imaginationor is the other way quicker?

Purchased because of the favorable reviews here and in magazines. Installed as second drive in Gateway machine with Win 98. Formatted partitioned and allowed to burn in for 5 days. On fifth day started upgrade to WinXP Pro. Drive failed totally during reformat. IBM diagnostics showed device failure so I've sent it in for warranty service. Will be without the drive for nearly 4 weeks. Maybe unusual experience given the reputation of the drive but the slow service for replacement is problematic.
It's definately not a 20 degree bag as my son and I were freezing in 45-50 degree weather. The bag is fluffy but the lining is a bit itchy if you're not wearing long pants/shirt. Roomy though.

For 60 bucks this is a good vest to try and see if weighted vests will work for you.It is one size fits all.It fits well and doesn't move around but the arm holes are a little tight when reaching out in front. Otherwise the fit is ok.It is a little tough to put on loaded with weight.Not as comfortable as the X Vest but it is 1/3 the price.If you know you want one and will use it I suggest the X vest.But as I stated this one is good to see if this type of exercise will work for you.

It's a very simple product so there isn't much to say. It's a weighted vest so that you can burn more calories and build up muscle while doing regular activities or going for a walk. There isn't a lot of room for error or excellence--it's a weight vest and it works thanks to gravity and biomechanics. There is one small problem

GABRIEL'S BLOCKBUSTER ALBUM.RUINED BY MEDIOCRE SOUND QUALITY KNOCKING A FIVE STAR CLASSIC DOWN TO THREE STARS. DO NOT BUY THE ORIGINAL BUT GET THE REMASTERED VERSION INSTEAD.Released in 1986 this was Gabriel's blockbuster album. And it deserved it. This is just great from beginning to end. It features great collaborations with Kate Bush and Laurie Anderson.Unfortunately coming out in 1986 the CD sound quality was mediocre. This was very suprising for Gabriel who had embraced digital technology years earlier. The sound is flat with limited dynamic range.Many of the early CD's had mediocre sound quality which gave rise to the vinyl snobs who thought CD's could never sound as good as LP's. But it was just a bad translation to the digital technoology. Today CD's sound much better than they did 20 years ago. Which is why you see so many 'remaatered' CD's today. That includes the complete Gabriel catalog.Not only being the most popular Gabriel CD it is his best. That is saying a lot since he has had many very good CD's.

After flirting with commercial success through his first several albums and having several modest hits Peter Gabriel finally broke into the commercial consciousness.'Security' began to open up the fears and paranoias on 'Peter Gabriel 3'-- yeah it had some of that but it emphasized the world elements and introduced a somber reflective side to the dense dark music on '3'. And it also introduced a funky modern sound. 'So' is really the reconciliation of all of these elements. Once again supported by guitarist David Rhodes bassist Tony Levin and drummer Jerry Marrotta (Larry Fast is sadly not to be found on this record) Gabriel augments his old team with drummer Manu Katche and guitarist/producer Daniel Lanois and several guests including violinist L. Shankar drummer Stewart Copeland (of the Police) singers Youssou N'Dour Kate Bush and Laurie Anderson bassist Bill Laswell and guitarist Nile Rodgers.The album's opener really displays the new styles here at its best-- 'Red Rain' is a ballad but it moves its got an undercurrent of funkiness to it similarly 'Don't Give Up' (featuring a duet with Kate Bush) again as a ballad (and a dark one) is bass driven with a funk undercurrent and gospel bridge. These two are absolutely stunning and unique in music even to this day. While 'Mercy Street' is a bit more traditional in its structure it is another incredible ballad with a stunning vocal harmony arrangement in the chorus.The funk elements come out stronger in a couple other (and more famous) album tracks 'Sledgehammer' and 'Big Time'. Modern synth-driven in many ways with incredible bass courtesy of Tony Levin these two are monsters that arrived on the scene at a perfect time. My only complaint is that they like the largely straightahead pop of 'That Voice Again' are a drift both lyrically and musically from what Gabriel excels at-- taking pain darkness other elements of people's lives and making them internal and personal. Look at 'Don't Give Up'-- it sounds like he wrote it about himself but its about a Depression photograph. These are great songs but they're a bit too clean and pop for my tastes.'We Do What We're Told' and 'This is the Picture' move closer in the direction of 'Security' or '3' but seem a bit unnatural given the synth layering on them.Of course its the album closer thats the most famous 'In Your Eyes' is really the strongest demonstration of Gabriel's world music influences on this one its really a quite nice song admittedly it was played into the ground for a long time. Nonethless years later I've been able to enjoy it.Its a decent album. Gabriel's done better but this might be the best place to start. However for new fans I'd caution listening closely to the darker material like 'Mercy Street' and 'Don't Give Up' and see how that suits you its really more in line with Gabriel's other work than the pop songs are.
It was OK I already listened So more than 20 years ago... I purchased it because it was cheap and I never got music from amazon. Thanks.
Just for one song I got this Cd Red Rain;if you haven't play this song in your stereo you don't know yet what you missing but play it loud.

An album so close to being a masterpiece but doesn't quite make it. Some odd sounding tracks spoil it but if you can overlook them buy this alone for the beautiful track 'In Your Eyes'. Who could forget the clever video for 'Sledgehammer' that song is included on this album as well as the great 'Big Time'. The duet with Kate Bush 'Don't Give Up' is impressive probably a little dragged out but worth listening to. Skip the boring 'Red Rain' track. Nevertheless in a nutshell Peter Gabriel's best album to date.
I've been wanting this album for a very long time so I finally just got it! I really love Peter Gabriels voice!

This is the album where the dam burst open and Gabriel became a bona fide arena level superstar. Prior to the release of 'So' Gabriel had a solid loyal cult following of old Genesis heads and fans of his more sparse solo materiel. 'So' burst on the scene with the smash single 'Sledgehammer' and Gabriel's career was off to the races. A lot of people love this album and think it is the high point of Gabriel's career. For me it is the continuation of a downhill slide that would culminate in his next disappointing release 'Us' a few years later. 'So' is not a bad album but I don't think it is a great album either. Gabriel's timing just happened to be perfect as he exploited the use of the music video to promote the singles son this disc. Gabriel was a true pioneer in this regard and his videos for 'Sledgehammer' 'Big Time' and 'Don't Give Up' were truly groundbreaking for their time. It is just too bad that the actual songs were not as good as the videos were. Ok maybe I am being too harsh as these songs are all ok but compared to the deeper more thought provoking material of his earlier career much of this could be seen as fluff. The album does contain some great tracks however including the opener 'Red Rain' the brooding 'Mercy Street' and the closing love song 'In Your Eyes' which will forever be associated with the famous scene from the movie 'Say Anything'. 'So' is far from Peter Gabriel's best work but it is not his worst either. I would rate it around 3.5 stars as I find it a rather mixed bag.

This feature does have good qualities. The casting is spot on the cinematography great the character development good. It has the 'feel' of a good western epic. One doesn't get the impression that any corners were cut.Unfortunately the pacing is glacial. There just isn't enough story to fill the 193 minutes of screen time. Worse one of the story lines is wrapped up far too quickly despite the extensive build up it was given. The other story line conclusion is far more satisfactory but the wait seems interminable.In short this story could have been done on just one of the dvds. Not a bad western by any means but definitely flawed.
regurgitated new age channeling belive it or not I havent heard from the other world beings yet and I am very disappionted.

Glad to hear something different come along. A few of the songs on this CD are a little boring in my opintion. However the better songs more than make up for it. Five or six good quality songs on this CD. It is good to hear a real songwriter and singer for once in a while.

I purchased this because I love the song Honey and the Moon which turned out to be the best song on the album. The rest of the album was just mediocre. The use of spiritual references were throughout the album. I'm not saying this was a bad thing but in this case none of the spiritual referances reached me other than the song You've Been Loved. It is the other song that in my opinion carries the album. I still would recommend the purchase of this album if for no other reason than to support the artist that could write such a beautiful song as Honey and the Moon. Hopefully he has more songs like this one in him.
Coughlans Tube Tent

Like many other reviewers I measured this movie against my own law school experience. In the early 70's law school was very politicized a reality conveniently ignored in this movie. Thus while Hart played by Timothy Bottoms has the signature long hair of 70's social concern his character is left to joust with the vagaries of all-too-selfish love and desire rather than meaning.Like a child seeking his stern father's approaval the main character cultishly devotes himself to professor Kingsfield (John Houseman) the aloof high-priest of Harvard Law School and Hart is content to vie to join the privileged hierarchy of the Church of the Bar.What we receive is a conformist messages from the film

I love gardening but am not the best at designing gardens so I frequently look for books to give me ideas about designs. This one has quite a few nice designs will full plant lists but unfortunately it was lacking on designs for my area or zone. Only one garden in the entire book fit my zone which is 28. I would suggest that in the future each garden design includes substitutions for plants to make it fit in other areas or zones.

According to the description the shade of this liner is not black or brown - it's mahogany. Let's be clear - it's dark brown.Cake liners have always been difficult for me but this one is particularly so. It goes on more easily wet than dry. When a dry application was tried there was either not enough color or so much that it smudged.As for the therapy - where does that come in????

I was thrilled when I found this for my daughter but was rather disappointed when it arrived. It is very small about the size of a smaller notecard. The pictures inside are fabulous just very small. The price printed on the back of the book is cheaper than the price I paid for it. If only they were bigger even for a couple of dollars more I think they would have been worth 5 stars.
I agree to some extent with the recent two reviewers

I love Clive James' writing - especially his wry style of combining haughty superciliousness with biting self-deprecation often within the space of one line. He writes like he speaks with a verbose sarcasm and throughout reading May Week Was In June it's almost impossible not to hear his nasal scoffing tones narrating the book for you.And while this third (and final?) instalment in his autobiographical memoirs (following the hugely funny Unreliable Memoirs and equally hilarious Falling Towards England) contains the familiar elements of James' comedic style it doesn't quite measure up to its two predecessors.Unreliable Memoirs where James told of his childhood days in post-war suburban Sydney didn't have to exert any effort whatsoever to raise a laugh

This third volume of unreliable memoirs picks up where the previous volume (Falling Towards England) let off. James in these books is interesting yet not as funny at least to me as it seems the things he is describing should be. I definitely need to give his fiction a try.The nice thing about reading a writer's biography like this is to realize that you are not alone. It is much too easy for me to think that I am the only one with trouble concentrating on the matter at hand instead of flirting with one passion after the other.
It's okay The quality seems fine Product was shipped promptly and in new condition.I really like how well the pictures are labeled.The quality seems fine
Frued's approach to sex and psychoanalytic interpretations can be inflammatory or make perfect sense. This book highlights some of the core ideas. Worth a look. --PJ Adams author of Freud's Revenge

The main reason for me to purchase this products was to play multi region DVDs. Unfortunately it does not play all multi region DVDs I have. Besides not being able to play multi region DVDs as they claimed to be it is a okay DVD play has built in 1080p upscale. Plus it is $30.00 cheaper than BestBuy store.Also the DVD player would not play any music CDs or DVDs. The error 'no disc' message was showing up on the player display. Sent it back on following day and received a replacement unit in no time and I was pleased with fast turn around time.

Yes this DVD player upscales (as opposed to upconverts like the category suggests) to 1080p outputs HDMI to fulfill DRM & HDCP and plays video and audio files from a flash drive. However it'll only play WMV and JPEGs as video formats through the flash drive. This is incredibly poor considering the player itself will play a slew of formats off of DVD & CD media (DVD-R DVD+R DVD-RW DVD+RW VCD SVCD WMA WMV MPEG-2 MPEG-4 MP3 CDA WAV etc.). Why they didn't program the firmware to work pulling those same formats off of the flash drive I have no idea but it is the main reason for the average rating. If you plan on never using the USB port then the player works as expected. The upscaling quality is pretty good but in some cases of 'you get what you pay for' this product is no different. There are better quality upscaling players out there if you're willing to pay for them. It is a good player and does as promised for the $90 price tag.

I bought this model to improve my upconverting performance for my legacy DVDs. I had been using my Xbox360 to play DVDs into my 1080P 40' Samsung LCD TV. After reading a review comparing the Xbox unfavorably to a high-end Denon upconverting DVD player I decided to look for a better player. I brought home the Pioneer and discovered the Xbox360 performs this task better. Note to self sales staff typically know NOTHING.

I've had the player for just over 3 months. And I have probably powered through 1000+ hours of videos. Mostly DVDs playing in the background since I can't seem to get the player to hold the signal to the receiver to play a CD for any extended period of time.Seems to give up playing after 3-4 hours of straight movie watching. Then I have to turn it off and wait a couple of hours or the next day. It's in a well ventilated area so I'm not sure why it may be overheating or something. The TV screen just turns to a red screen. At first I thought it was my new TV but the TV played just fine.The other thing I noticed is that it doesn't seem to like double-sided DVD. This is where it locks up the most. I have alot of double sided DVD probably 75% of my movie collection is on double-sided DVDs.So I would say it lacks some performance for power users. And the double sided DVD thing is killing me. I've had to use another DVD player on many occasions to finish watching a movie.
This is my second DV-400K and this one keeps locking up on me forcing me to unplug it to get it to work. The other one I bought works better so far. It does play almost anything I have thrown at it.
Anyone who thinks that Powaqqatsi is 'the worst of Phil' needs to have his head examined.

If you own Watermark Shepherd Moons The Memory of Trees or A Day Without Rain you already own this album. As much as I love the past work of Enya Amarantine breaks no new ground whatsoever.While Enya's continued work with Roma Ryan and Nicky Ryan is one of her strengths in terms of harmony of artistic vision it is also her greatest weakness on another level

I was curious about Enya when I first heard of her; due to my love to U2's music and knowing that Enya became Irland's second biggest musical export after U2 (she's from Irland such a bad stereotype on my part).There's no way one's can deny her beautiful voice and remarkable style but I came to think that all her music has the same redundant theme when it comes to lyrics or music.This album reached the top 10 in both the UK and the US peaked at number 3 in Germany won the Grammy award for best new age album for 2007 and I'm in disbelief and trying to understand what is so special about this album.The reason I'm giving it three stars is that she is a hard working artist with glorious presence on the stage(at least she's not winking at the audience and acting cheesy like il Divo boys). With the inimitable style she has maybe it is expected to have a theme in all her albums but the lyrics of this album don't measure up to the standards she had in her other albums and they are either too repetitive and empty or just beyond my mental capacity. I'll go with the first choice; the lyrics are repetitive and empty.

I felt the words 'caged bird' were appropriate for the title of my review simply for the fact that I believe that Enya is a caged bird. Her creativity has been caged by monotony and the inability to try something new.If you want a sure and time-tested formula this is the album for you. Enya really does not re-invent the wheel. For a fan of her musicianship I think she is sadly held back by Nicky and Roma Ryan. She needs to assert herself more and find new songwriters. Amarantine? What the heck? Poor word choice and the song is sickenly dull. Amarantine the word doesn't even sound pretty. It doesn't feel right in a song either. Amarantine sounds like it should have belonged on Memory of Trees. Somebody Said Goodbye sounds like it could belong on Memory of Trees.The two best songs on the album are The River Sings and Water Shows the Hidden Heart. She sounds her best. The River Sings also helps to cut through the dull slo-mo of songs. They sound so similiar and run into each other. I also would like to say I hated Sumiregusa. I know this probably an ode to her Japanese fans. However her layered singing drowns out the beauty of the words.If you don't mind a lack of change and are an Enya fan I am sure you would love this album.If you haven't heard much of Enya's material and have never bought any of her CDs I recommend you stick to her first three albums - Celts Watermark and Shepherds Moon. They are her best work.She needs a new songwriter for starters. She also needs to experiment with instruments more. Her samples are getting old.I hate to be harsh but I am just not happy with her artistic offerings this time around. She has so much more potential.Finally I give her three stars simply for the fact that her voice is beautiful and her albums are always well produced. Beyond that this album really is a two.

Amarantine unlike all of Enya's previous work sadly underwhelmed me. It is a good listen but with a few exceptions I didn't feel I was hearing anything new. Enya's albums all have a distinct `sound' to them that which identifies them from the other albums. Not Amarantine.The good first. There are some great songs on Amarantine. 'It's in the Rain' the haunting 'Drifting' (the album's only instrumental) the furious 'The River Sings' the anthemic 'Less than a Pearl'... Amarantine has its winners. There's even the haiku-like 'Sumiregusa' entirely in Japanese which is a pleasant grower.However there are also some tracks which sound fairly it must be said unspectacular. 'A Moment Lost' and 'Amid the Falling Snow' are both such dull and uncreative tracks that I'm surprised that Enya put them on the album at all. Even the filler songs of The Memory of Trees were wonderful. That's the other thing what about the creativity in the instrumentation? You can really hear in each Enya album just judging from the sound what album it is. Not so with Amarantine. It lacks that special sound identifiable with itself. As good as the aforementioned tracks are Amarantine lacks that 'wow' factor which her other albums sport. Normally Enya's music transports you tugging at your heartstrings and mesmerizing you. I missed that feeling immensely when listening to Amarantine and it's a real shame.Another problem is one that lyricist Roma Ryan is responsible for. Three tracks are in the fictional language Loxian created by Roma herself. In the booklet each of these songs has the lyrics in Loxian as well as the English translation which is a welcome addition. However Loxian while beautiful to the ears has an alphabet completely unrelated to the Latin alphabet making following these songs lyrically impossible which is quite off-putting. There are also no songs in Enya's native Irish which is rather sad. Irish might have made some songs sound a bit more interesting.For those of you wanting more elaboration I will go deeper into each individual track.LESS THAN A PEARLA breahttaking composition with a moody and yet gloriously inspiring atmosphere. The chorus of vocals in the Loxian language weave a haunting layer of sound. A very strong way to open the album; definitely one of the best tracks.AMARANTINEThis is the first time the album's title track is not the opener and perhaps it was for the best here. 'Amarantine' is very plain and 'safe'. And the lovey-dovy lyrics just sound unimaginative on Roma Ryan's part. A sadly prophetic taste for what's to come.IT'S IN THE RAINThis is one track I am taken with; understated and low-key but steady. The melody is strong and gripping. A moody introspective track that has its own way of gripping the listener.IF I COULD BE WHERE YOU AREThis song's beauty is its simplicity - it's all vocal and strings and is a haunting thing in its own right. It reminds me of some of Enya's b-sides like 'I May Not Awaken' only more hopeful and stirring.THE RIVER SINGSThe first track I was truly taken with - an energetic fast and feisty song with a gorgeous thunderous sound. It's especially a pity here that you can't really follow the Loxian lyrics because it's another of the strongest tracks on the album.LONG LONG JOURNEYNot one of the album's worst songs but it's to thank its charm and catchiness that it gets away with its painfully unimaginative sound.SUMIREGUSAAnother winner slow and dripping with atmosphere. The haiku-like lyrics in Japanese are very moving.SOMEONE SAID GOODBYEMaybe it's just because of the pure melancholy of this song but I've never been able to really warm up to it. It divides people but I think it's one of the best English-language tracks on the album in that it weaves a mood so far removed from what one might potentially expect from Enya's work. I see some of Enya's emotion seep through here.A MOMENT LOSTSpeaking of things you can expect this song is so plain and unimaginative that it borders on plain boring. It doesn't even sound fully composed. Waste of disc space a dire song.DRIFTINGNow we're talking. Perhaps my biggest personal favourite; a gorgeous pristine instrumental (which this album could definitely use more of). The cello running through helps make this melody downright goosebump-inducing. This is magic and proves once again that Enya doesn't need lyrics if the music is strong in its own right.AMID THE FALLING SNOWThis song took me a long time to warm up to. If anything it has a great chorus and the final thirty seconds are very appealing. But the lyrics don't tell me anything really and the melody is fairly dire in retrospect.WATER SHOWS THE HIDDEN HEARTFor a closer this is a fairly anticlimatic song in the sense that for such a lyric-central melody you can't follow the lyrics in question. And the melody while nice and soothing isn't strong enough to be a closer. While this is a moving song it has to be the weakest closer to any of Enya's albums.Amarantine is certainly Enya's poorest release but it still has it good songs to speak of. The principle flaw as I see it is the sing-songy element in a lot of the songs; I miss the powerful melodies that were above that. As it stands we've heard it all before and portrayed much stronger than here. The artwork ironically illustrates the album perfectly; a whole lot of dull whites with some delicious reds thrown in. And Winter Came... would see Enya return to form but Amarantine is strictly for Enya's most devoted fans.

The reason for the three stars is there is nothing new on this CD. They should have titled it Greatest Hits of Enya and been done with it. I'm not saying the songs are terrible; I'm just saying I already have all the music on prior CD's. Buy it if you are a first time person listening to Enya.

I first heard 'Orinoco Flow' in a department store at the tender age of twelve and have been bewitched ever since by the sheer magic of Enya's music. I can think of no singer I admire or love more and with the possible exception of Loreena McKennitt no one whose music can touch so many different emotions. So I was thrilled when 'Amarantine' was released and popped it into my CD player the first chance I got expecting to be bewitched again. And it truly saddens me to say that I wasn't.Don't get me wrong - it's not a bad CD. I would still rather listen to 'Amarantine' than Hilary Duff any day. But given the choice between 'Amarantine' and 'A Day Without Rain' there's no question that my choice would be the latter. The truth is 'Amarantine' feels like a rehash of 'A Day Without Rain' and not a very inspired one either. The parallels are easy to draw. 'It's in the Rain' is 'Wild Child' 'Long Long Journey' is 'On My Way Home' (okay not on 'A Day Without Rain' but that's what it sounds like) 'Amarantine' is 'Flora's Secret' and 'Someone Said Goodbye' is 'One By One.' And with the partial exception of a few tracks ('Someone Said Goodbye' and 'Less Than a Pearl' for example) they all lack that unnameable quality that can tug at your heart like nothing else.Granted it is interesting to compare the parallel songs. 'Someone Said Goodbye' stands out particularly because it takes the exact opposite stance from 'One By One.' Where that song's refrain was 'Don't say goodbye' this one asks 'Is there a reason why you never want to say goodbye?' It helps that of all the album's songs 'Someone Said Goodbye' sounds the most like Enya inspired Enya at her best. Too many of the other songs suffer from either not-very-compelling music or lyrics far more pedestrian than we're used to hearing that pull the music down. I love Enya for her ethereal music her entrancing voice and lyrics like those in 'Only Time' - lyrics that mean something. Words like 'I wonder how you can endure/All I've said all I say to you' sound out-of-place on an Enya CD. Let me say it again

I have been long awaiting this new album and was very happy to see that Enya had come out with a new album but when I put it on to listen I was a little bit disappointed in what I heard. As always there is some beautiful tracks. My favorite being track #3 but some of the songs are just dull and sound all alike. As always Nicky Ryan's lyrics are beautiful but many are very contrived and pop like. The album is missing the warmth that the Celts or Shepard Moons or even A Day With Out Rain had. It is missing that beautiful dreamy celtic sound that was once there. In some ways it seems that Enya has sold out to the more mainstream pop market which disappointments me a bit since I orginally turned to Enya to escape this kind of sound. Instead of buying this album I would recommend downloading some select songs from itunes and buying The Celts or Shepard Moons instead.

I hate to say this but Enya has run out of things to say. Even to the point that Roma Ryan has made up a fictional language to burble about. 'Amarantine' is something you've heard before and often. Even if it takes Enya five years between albums you get the vague impression that this was what you just listened to.Darn shame that. The billowing clouds of multi-Enya's singing like a blissed out choir were what made her great. There was no-one else out there that made songs anything like 'Orinoco Flow' or 'Storms In Africa.' But we're talking almost 20 years ago and 'Amarantine' just sounds like warmed over material. The songs all waft and drift and instead of inspiring bliss...they just vanish. Only the generic ballad 'Someone Said Goodbye' sounds like it could transcend the album we're listening to because this all just runs into itself like cotton candy fluff for aging new-agers.Maybe it was too much to expect that Enya and her collaborators could maintain brilliance forever. But like sonic architect Enigma (or even going back to The Alan Parsons Project) eventually the striking original becomes the banal. Unfortunately that is what we have with 'Amarantine.'

At age 16 I purchased 'Watermark'. I was in 10th grade it was February 1989 and the type of music Enya was making was very different from everything else at the time. I saw the video for 'Orinoco Flow' on VH1 and was sold (as were my friends). Well I'm 33 now and cynical and jaded (as I was at 16 too). Enya doesn't fool me anymore. I might as well listen to 'Watermark' and 'Shepherd Moons' as listen to 'Amarantine' Enya's sixth studio album. They're all pretty much interchangeable. The only reason her last album 'A Day Without Rain' sold over 6 million copies was due to a strange coincidence of 9/11 and a remix of 'Only Time' a version that wasn't even on that album. I hated the remix and I thought how cliche that the American public while in mourning and shock would turn to 'Only Time' of all songs (after all 'A Day Without Rain' had been out for almost a year with no notice).So 'Amarantine' like all of Enya's other works is soothing and pure escapist new age music. As with all of her albums it's pick and choose amongst the songs. I thought the title track 'Long Long Journey' 'Sumiregusa' and 'Someone Said Goodbye' could all be included on a new Enya best of compilation (which I could make since I own all of her albums). To listen to 'Amarantine' all the way through its 45 minute length is truly no different than listening to her other albums.I like Enya but I am artistically disappointed by her stubborness to NOT try anything new musically. She uses the same songwriters and producers for each album and makes one new release every five years (the real reason for this must be because she wouldn't sell the same model of car every year consumers would get suspicious!) In this way she hoodwinks the public because every five years the general public has forgotten who she is and therefore there is a new flock of sheep who have never heard of her to buy her music.How many more years will Enya continue to recycle her past work? She's a multi-millionaire now why not try something completely different? What has she got to lose at this point? My three star rating mean average folks. It's okay but nothing new or great. I'll be here in another five years to say the same thing (you can still read my post five years ago about her last album 'A Day Without Rain'!)

After listening to the samply of this CD I must agree with others Reviewer this CD is a disappointment.The lyric is not as good as before and too many repeated. Although the music is new but it need more to make me want to buy the CD.Enya is one of the best artist I know but are we buying her reputation or just the music itself? I am not buying anything just because of someone's reputation I pay my money for what I like. And this album is just not my cup of tea.

...but I don't feel that I've added a lot to my collection by purchasing this CD. Unless I'm reading the lyric insert as I listen I have trouble remembering which album I'm listening to! That said the title track is quite nice and one that WILL probably make the jump to my iPod playlist. The rest....we'll see.

As a long time Enya fan (starting with the ground breaking album Watermark) I found Amarantine to be a let down as there is nothing new here that has not been heard before on her previous albums. In Amaratine it appears that Enya has finally run out of new concepts. After a long break from her last album I was anxiously looking forward to new material along the lines of Shepard Moons or The Memory of Trees. Watch out for what you wish for as that is what we got. This in no way diminishes the work Enya has produced to date as I still enjoy her previous albums I simply wish that Amarantine had continued the tradition of unique surprises.

I've collected everything worth having of Enya's even a lot of her singles (that means selections with a lot of duplication which renders having ALL of her work not worth the money) and decided I had to have this album as soon as I saw it was coming out.Unusually for Enya you don't get any Latin or Gaelic on this CD you get three Loxian tunes (I think I've read that this made up language has some Lord of the Rings Inspiration) and one in Japanese (Sumiregusa). I think that the overall tone of the CD is somewhat slower than past efforts it's more of a backgrond music album to my way of thinking because of this.It might not be the album for a new Enya listener to start with but established fans will find a lot to like here. I don't consider it to be Enya's best but Amarantine is much better than most CD's out there it is worth owning. I only hope she doesn't wait 5 years for the next one.

it's enya therefore it can't be below 3 stars... but it just doesn't excite me except for 'sumiregusa' 'the river sings' and the opening track. those three are BEAUTIFUL. the rest is slightly different than what she's done before in that it's average-sounding. it's like music for people in their late 50's rather than dreamy music for everyone. ADWR was dreamy but boring. this is just boring. i can't get into this one but i still don't hate it. maybe time will change my opinion...

I found this CD disappointing -- partly because most of the tracks are dreary and downbeat and even worse they ring annoyingly in my head! I heard 'Amarantine' once and for days it wouldn't get out of my head -- like a bad advertisement jingle. Same with 'Amid the Falling Snow' which I would've otherwise liked okay.Having said that I do have two favorites on this CD

I'm listening to a song now from the album in the hope that it will inspire me to write kinder things about the album Amarantine by Enja.This is new age which means 'voice layering synthesized backdrops and reverberations' according to Wikipedia which probably serves the same purpose of sunglasses--to hide many sins. A voice without range can go on forever. Nevertheless the melodies are soothing especially in a beautifully decorated main room with a roaring fire in a Vermont Bed & Breakfast. The sound can be captivating even if the words seem like Neil Diamond songs with no rhyme or reason. I find the melody especially of the feature song to be pleasing. It's great to listen to by a roaring fire but in my apartment that would mean the bookshelf or the curtains were going up in which case I would be in definite need of soothing. The words on the other hand can almost put me in a bad mood with their lack of message and repetition once twice three times a

Thanks to a national catastrophe that is 9.11 Enya's A Day Without Rain soared on the charts selling some 7 million copies with some clever mixing of Only Time which saw sentimental Americans embracing the song giving her her first ever American Top 10 hit.Now some 4 years later Enya returns with Armarantine which fans have been waiting for with bated breath. The result? Amarantine is brief and typical Enya but the fact is that most tracks suffer from the fate of being rather indistinctly slow and unmemorable. And it has finally come to show that Enya's formula might already be wearing too thin for its own good.However all is not lost. The sublime and uplifting The River Sings is good reason why we still hold faith in Enya giving us something spirited. And there is Sumiregusa the Japanese haiku-inspired track used in a Panasonic ad that drove fans to a frenzy speculating her new album would be out soon last year. Having said that the track is beautifully serene and placid. The instrumental Drifting is befitting as part of a score for some major motion picture due to its lushness.Amarantine isn't going any where near Shepherd Moons or any of her previous albums but it'd still give Enya a decent run anyway. Not bad for a woman who sold 50 million records by shielding away from any limelight and putting out records at her own whim and fancy.
I have all Enya's albums but this one is simply not as good as any of her previous ones.

I have been a fan of Enya since I was 14. Ever since then I got hooked to her music and even Clannad's. I find that Amarantine is very mild by her standard. There is something to do with the order of her songs. The first song 'Less than a pearl' gets off on a good start. Unfortunately the hit song 'Amarantine' is second in line and it just ruins your appetite for every songs right after that. My recommendation would be put your CD player on RANDOM. It feels much better to listen to few other good songs before you finally reached 'Amarantine'.When you purchase this album you will enjoy the authenticity in Enya's voice. You know nobody can sing it like her and that's exactly what you are paying for. Amarantine lacks the effect of giving you goosebumps and that's very hard to come by when we are talking about Enya. But it does reduce the craving for the past five years since Days Without Rain. This CD will make a great stocking stuffer and that's only because the recipient will appreciate that he/she doesn't have to pay money for it.

Well I've heard both sides of the story here about this album. Some say it's horrible and predictable and others say that it's really great. I personally think that it's in the middle. It's not horrible because they're using the old Enya sound still - which is a really good sound but they're not really progressing much in any direction. It reminds me of alot of other bands that come up with a good sound but don't want to venture out of it. Why? Well in this case - I think it's because they don't have any ideas as to where to go. And well now looking at the sales chart for this why would someone want to make the effort when instead you can put out stuff like your older material and hit #1 on sales charts? Although it's really sad to see Enya have to take 5 years to produce this because I really doubt that all 5 years were spent writing this...it's just not that groundbreaking. Now if they had come out with something really different - but still Enya - then I could see the 5 years but it's really annoying to wait for that large amount of time just to see new material be alot like 'A Day Without Rain.'In any case - I can say that this album will please devoted Enya followers or if you're new to Enya but liked ADWR....but if you're someone like me who doesn't enjoy purchasing the same album twice - I'd recommend just buying her older stuff if you don't have it already and enjoying that. Or if you want a few new moderately good songs from Enya just download them off of itunes because since hearing this album from a friend - I came to the conclusion that if I had bought that album I would feel a bit ripped off and as if I could have just spent 3 or 4 dollars on itunes downloading the few standout songs.In conclusion - this is not groundbreaking or a standout album but rather - it's just average and will probably get boring the next time that I listen to it.

I've been an Enya Fan for many years now and enjoyed all her previous releases and singles and the COllections immensely but this Album I found real dissapointing sorry. As if many of the songs especially from the second half of the album are low edged b-sides which never made it onto any previous release. I like about 4-5 Songs on this album at the most
The CD is good but not as enjoyable as the two I previously bought.

I purchased this album on the day it was released. I was absolutely thrilled as it had been several years since 'A Day Without Rain' and I was eager to sample the fresh material of 'Amarantine.' Sadly I was disappointed. I only listened to the album once or twice before tucking it in my car's CD holder and not touching it. Very recently I decided to pull it out and give it a second chance with my newly-lowered expectations.The one thing that I dislike most about this album is that there's nothing that makes it distinguishable from other Enya albums. In the past all of Enya's albums have had their own distinct themes (ex. the melancholy moods of 'Shepherd Moons' the glorious exotic vibrance of 'The Memory of Trees'). With 'Amarantine' there is nothing distinct. At best it's a collection of dewey-eyed love songs and sounds mostly like a bunch of b-sides filler tracks and throwaway cuts from previous albums. Heck even the album artwork is boring and ordinary something I'd never expected from Enya.One thing I've discovered is that it is mainly the older fans who dislike this album. I would probably be considered an 'older fan.' I have all of Enya's albums including the fabulous 'Only Time' boxed set and yet this is the first album to really disappoint me. The disappointment lies not so much in the music but in the lyrics which are absolutely dreadful. One comes to expect lush storytelling and thoughtful meditations from Enya's lyrics... but with 'Amarantine' the listener is left with shallow immature romantical notions and constant repititions. One can only use the words 'heart' 'tears' and 'love' so many times before they become nails-on-chalkboard cringeworthy.Here are my thoughts on each individual track

I never thought I would ever find myself using the term 'Disheartening' to describe Enya's work. I have been a near obsessed fan for as many years as I am old just about. I have all ofher imports her box-sets her VHS and DVD's... and unlike any other artist who decides to make we wait between 5-8 painstaking years for something new- I always found it was worth the wait.Until Amarantine. I cannot even begin to express my extreme disappointment in this Album. It's apparentfrom reading other reviews I am not alone in this. I don't want people to forget that Enya actually consists of three people... Enya herself the vocalist and instrumentalist Nicky Ryan the producer and Roma Ryan the poet and lyracist.It should be apparent to everyone that the problem with this latest work is *not* Enya herself. If anything her voice is the heavenly powerhouse it always has been andher English has improved tremendously. No longer should we Enya fans have to translate for our friends who sit stumped over the words. The words that Roma Ryan weaves still conjur up majestic images and longing emotions that spin tales leaving us breathless. She is a lyrical genius. The problem is Nicky Ryan who seems no longer capable of challenging Enya herself musically. In fact with Amarantine we here her in various themes influenced by their previous outing 'A Day WIthout Rain' specifically threads of their worldwide smash 'Only Time.' Perhaps Nicky was hoping to mimic that success unfortunately it fell entirely short of even modest Enya fans.What wrong with this Album? Thetracks seem simply exploitive of Rnya herself. They could be crap and we'd still purchase it. 'Long Long Journey' is far to reminiscent of a child's tune like London Bridge Is Falling down... with the traditional Enya-esque Ooh's and Ahh's thrown in for continuity. 'It's In The Rain' has lovely lyrics (Typical of Roma) but he theme to which it's set diminishes it's potential beyond redemption. Of course you will hear threads of their first outing 'The Celts.''Sumiregusa' a japanese inspired song was released actually last summer and used in a panasonic commercial. While it's etheral quality and overall beauty got fans all over the globe excited about the forthcoming album it was overwhelmingly sad to see it included on the album for one would presume with over 5 years between the last album and this one more tracks could have been completed and ready for inclusion. 'Sumiregusa' and the reaction to it must have made them think we would have liked to have heard it on the album instead of as a single- which was even made available on Enya's website long before the release.'Amarantine' isnot without it's small gems though. The two best tracks on this Album are 'Someone Said Good-Bye' and 'Water shows the Hidden Heart' both of whish sshowcase Enya's vocal capability and Roma's lyrical savvy. Aside from that nothing on this album will have you singing along nothing echoes the Enya quality to which we have grown accustomed to and finally nothing is remotely as memorable as any of the track on her previous albums.Perhaps the most frustrating fact is while most of us die-hard fans accept the extraordinary amount of time between albums (So much time that most other musicians complete 2 or 3 albums.) but what is hard to accept that after the sour reception of this stinker we'll have to wait until 2010 before we get to see if this is just a blooper or in indeed the quality of Nicky's production skills are going downhill.

While `A Day Without Rain' was Enya's summertime album so to say and provided a refreshing change from her usual sombre fare it was a relatively safe affair that really offered nothing new and verged on being mediocre and harmless. `Amarantine' doesn't completely recover from the signs of creative strain already showing in her previous outing but familiar tones from albums past particularly `Watermark' and `The Memory of Trees' will provide something satisfying for existing fans even if this work isn't the best way to be introduced to a songstress who has proven herself many times and better at that before.It stings a little to say that `Amarantine' contains material that doesn't bring itself above the meagre quality of filler but sadly it does. Dreary ballads with almost monotonous melodies and lacklustre arrangements like `It's in the Rain' `I Could Be Where You Are' and `A Moment Lost' contribute nothing to the album other than demonstrating the very worst that Enya's compositions can be should the creative sensibilities that she's exhibited frequently in the past leave her. `It's in the Rain' in particular is an example of how her signature sound of synthesised instruments and vocals could become dated dangerously soon. The title track is a by-the-numbers Enya song that is a highlight inasmuch as it is the title track. It is bland while pleasant and would be unsurprisingly found as a forgettable number on `A Day Without Rain'.Other songs are perhaps best described as shifty. `Someone Said Goodbye' is hummable but plays like a bluesy pop song running on strings instead of drums. The use of a novel language does nothing to help `Sumiregusa' and `Amid the Falling Snow' sounds like it belongs on a compilation of alternative Christmas carols. The lyrics on the entire album are mostly trite and repetitive I'm sorry to say and whatever attempts they make at creating a resonant emotional core fail quite embarrassingly. Even excerpts in Loxian from Roma Ryan's book read like nothing more than faux-philosophical musings that seem to settle for thinking that they cannot go wrong by making convenient references to mystical images and ultimately simplistic metaphors.But the Loxian songs do stand out on this album and it's a pity that there are only three. Be it the sheer invention of the language or the premises that are depicted in it Enya and her team appear to have been intrigued somewhat by Roma Ryan's conception which seems to have revealed to them undiscovered creative spaces. That is a treat precisely because it's what listeners know Enya does best - charting new creative realms and building on them with her music. It's in the exploration of new worlds which always appeals to the imagination that Enya and her song-writing duo shine. `Less Than A Pearl' is an assured and quietly sublime opening matched by a relatively epic conclusion on `Water Shows the Hidden Heart' that plays comfortably with its occasional classical-sounding tinges. `The River Sings' is perhaps the best track on the album absolutely riveting and displaying sheer adventure in the mix of beats and vocals. More importantly it shows what's distinctive about Enya and that quality surely comes in no small part from her experiences with Clannad - which isn't a bad thing at all as `Watermark' and `Shepherd Moons' showed. It's a wonderful feeling when you know a song was simply inspired in its composition and `The River Sings' celebrates that with an easy comfortable and sparklingly energetic groove. In addition one should not forget `Drifting' the only instrumental piece which is a master class in how the unremarkable can be remarkably stirring. One doesn't feel the sting of pity from the lack of a trademark piano tune typically featured in her other albums.But even after an affecting finish one is still inclined to think that `Amarantine' isn't quite amaranthine (and yes - it's spelt with an `h'). While not quite as unmemorable as `A Day Without Rain' threatened to be a disturbingly contemporary creative headspace seems to have taken over - indeed since her previous work - depriving `Amarantine' of the unique sound that's come to be associated with Enya - romanticised ethereal echoes of the past that allow olden beauty to reach across the centuries and become truly transcendent by resonating with our hearts in our time. There isn't even really anything here that bears her beloved Celtic touch and that is woeful. `Amarantine' is quite pitifully less than a pearl and little more than a memory of what's been done much much more proficiently before.

Yes I know all artists grow and change and I am still a devoted Enya fan. But i have to confess I like her earlier work much more. I'm a little bothered by the sing-songy trend I see emerging in her work. I'm not getting the powerful larger than life images in my mind like i did with her first three CD's. This comes across more as Enya Lite. give me the old style massive sound I fell in love with years ago.

I've been a devoted Enya fan my whole life and after A Day Without Rain I eagerly awaited the next release for five years.The first thing I noticed when I listened to Amarantine was that Enya has changed over the years since ADWR. Most of the songs have an odd singsong-y quality to them that was not present in her previous work. The songs by and large have simpler melodies and I was disappointed by the lack of complexity. Enya's music normally entrances the listener and creates a state of mind all its own. I had great difficulty getting into that state with this album. In a way the songs reminded me of a small child more skipping around and 'me' focused than before. Many of the lyrics don't fit the melodies as they should and a lot of the lyric songs sound more as if they should have been instrumental pieces. I believe there was only one non-vocal piece on Amarantine and if some of the songs with lyrics had been left as instrumental pieces the album as a whole would have been more appealing.On to the good points songs like 'It's In the Rain' and 'The River Sings' evoked more of the feel of A Day Without Rain and Enya's older sound in general capturing the slightly mournful melodies in 'It's In the Rain' and the characteristic and energizing chants in 'The River Sings.' I hope that whenever Enya releases another album (and I hope that it will not be another five years) it will fall more along the lines of the music on A Day Without Rain. Overall this album sounds somewhat experimental and I hope that through this experiment Enya finds the best music she can produce.

Like so many other reviewers I too am a HUGE fan of Enya's and own all her albums listen to them regularly and have been long awaiting the release of a new album! Five years without a new Enya CD is a very long time so excitedly I purchased this CD the day it was released. First time listening to it I was indeed disappointed. It sounded as if--for all the talent that Enya has--that she has suddenly reduced her songs to a limited range of 4 or 5 notes up and down the scale---over and over and OVER again! Talk about monotony! Now however as I've listened to the CD about 15 times I'm beginning to hear more depth to the pieces and I'm starting to enjoy the CD more with each listen. I definitely feel that this CD is an 'acquired taste' and that it takes time and SEVERAL LISTENS to enjoy it. I unabashedly feel that this is NOT Enya's best work! One would think that after five dry years she would produce something really fantastic especially since there's only 12 songs on this CD. Like so many other reviewers have mentioned each song seems to sound so much like other Enya songs from the past--or worse like other songs on THIS very CD as they all tend to blend together and sound so much alike that you can't quite tell where one ends and another begins. That said however now that I've listened several times I'm beginning to appreciate it a bit more and can actually admit to LIKING several of the songs. (I am however still trying to figure out the NEED for a fictional Loxian language no matter how pleasant-sounding it might be....Can't we just stick to English and Gaelic?) I suppose my favorite song is 'The River Sings' because of its refreshing upbeatness in--what seems like--an otherwise sea of slothfulness (although I'm still trying to figure out the NEED for a FICTIONAL language [i.e. Loxian] on this CD no matter how pleasant-sounding it may be. Can't we just stick to English and Gaelic? Why the need to make one up for a music CD such as this? Afterall this music is NOT the soundtrack to a movie like Lord of the Rings...) For personal reasons I've become very attached to the song 'If I Could Be Where You Are' because when I listen to the song I think of my Mom who is in heaven and I wish I could 'find a way to bring her back home'. The hymm-like quality of this song coupled with the lyrics is very moving to me but as I said for personal reasons.(At the risk of repeating myself--but then why not? Enya surely does it....) so much of this CD is repetitive and redundant and it seems a bit like 'leftovers'. For example The song 'Long Long Journey' could well be titled 'On My Way Home Part II' and 'Somebody Said Goodbye' (the MOST redundant song on the CD) could be 'One by One
I have been listening to Enya since my early teens and enjoy her music. However on this CD I only like two songs so far and that's not good considering her past work.
This is another very pleasant CD by a great artist. If you are an Enya enthusiast you'll enjoy this work also. Not her best album but still a joy to listen to...

I like the ideas and the setting but the characters are so stiff-backed and awkward. I was cringing through all the dialogue. Nonetheless I was able to enjoy this book and the others because it moves at a good pace.

I have read with great enjoyment the other books in this series and I was really looking forward to reading 'The Sorcerer' but boy...it is sadly lacking what Whyte put into the other books in this series. I had a hard time forcing myself to read this one because it is so slow moving and just plain boring. It seems as if Whyte lost his train of thought here or was himself bored with the telling of the Camulod tale. Either way his editor needs a kick in the rear for letting this one be published as is.For those who are reading the series and haven't yet gotten to this one I do suggest you read it just to keep following the story to the end but I finally resorted to skiming paragraphs/pages just to get through the really boring parts.Very disappointing this book is.

I loved the first four books of Whyte's Camulod Chronicles but apparently he lost his way in Fort At River's Bend (book 5). Now in Sorcerer he has recovered quite a bit but still fails to hold a candle to his previous works.Finally Whyte resolves dozens of our expectations and dangling questions. Certain characters have died as we knew they must. Camulod is becoming less Roman and more like the Arthurian Britain we all know. Merlin has now become the sorcerer and Arthur has pulled the sword from the stone and become King of all Britain.Unfortunately the manner in which he did all this... left me far from impressed. While Whyte had spent immense detail on every little meaningless event in previous books he then chaotically rushed through these MAIN events we have been waiting for since The Skystone.It's a shame but after six books- I am no longer interested in how this series will turn out.

The Freud edge banding system occupies a unique niche between the household iron and multi-thousand dollar (aka 'real production') edgers. So far as I can tell it's the only option for semi-professional production of heat-set edge banding.I find it a highly compromised tool. As the old National Geographics used to say it's in a land of problems and promises. Conceptually it's a darn good idea. The execution could be a whole lot better.Let's look at edge banding for a minute. It's not much thicker than a business card (exclusive of adhesive)and only fractionally wider than the wood it is applied to. It takes a fair amount of heat to soften the glue. The guide system on a bander needs to hold material flat square and unbowed although everything that is being done previously almost guarantees the opposite.The EB100 sometimes does the trick. There's only so much precision one can expect from stamped steel guides. When the machine works it's a lot faster than the household iron. When it doesn't it's hard to resist the temptation to throw the sucker out the window. Although one can remove improperly applied edging it takes more effort than to apply it by hand in the first place.Freud should improve the guide system and the table on the EB100 to make it a truly useful machine. Machined precision guides would are necessary for this operation. And they shoud re-think using heat-set banding on a machine table that is subject to high temperatures. After 20 minutes of operation the front edge of the table peels up. This doesn't impair function it just looks like hell.I know woodworkers that get excellent results from this system. Despite significant experience with precision machinery I can't duplicate their results. Maybe if I were more skilled I could. I am uncomfortable with a machine that makes me guess continually.

This product worked well enough on a recent project that the customer was quite satisfied with the result. On the flip side since this item will only apply pre-glued hot melt adhesive product I'm finding the usefulness limited to white black or unfinished birch edgeband. If there were more variations of edgeband compatible with this machine would definitely rate 4 stars possibly 5 stars. Since I can't seem to find anything other pre-glued edgeband I find it's use limited.

I haven't watched a whole lot of movies lately butthis will tear you up...or apart. It's called 'BodyParts' starring Jeff Fahey and Kim Delaney (1988vintage).My e-mail bud Tina keeps telling me I shouldn't wastemy time with such drudge but how can a movie misswhen it'a all about a psycho female surgeon thatdisects the body of a man sentenced to death forbrutal murders? Disecting is onething...transplanting those parts on needy bodies isanother.Worth your time? You bet. It's a modern-dayFrankenstein with excellent performances by Fahey andDelaney.Though it may be a little corny and unbelieveable itis quite entertaining and mindless...which is what weneed now and then.In the horror genre this one gets a 3.5....definitelyworth a Friday Flick rental.
Bill Chrushank (the great Jeff Fahey) is Living the Dream

I was very excited to see all three of these movies on one disc. For the record this review is more about the quality versus the actual films. These movies are WONDERFUL and I would suggest anyone see all of them. Yes they are that good! (Especially His Girl Friday) However the quality of this disc is just plain horrible. And like one reviewer I at first attributed it to the age of the films. But when I saw two of these films on Turner Classic Movies they were just fine! So I thought the DVD should have been just as good. In His Girl Friday the sound was so blurred I could barely understand what was going on! The actual picture quality was bad as well. The screen continued to jump and was just as blurry and grainy as the sound. Charade was no better. I'd suggest you wait or look around for a better version of these films. Either way you should definitely see them!

Gritty entertaining story is nevertheless upstaged by excellent cinematography and direction. However not for those who can't take an unrelenting grim tone. Memorable ending with a BIT of a ray of sunshine in the final moments. The DVD utilized a pretty good print of the film (no major glitches) but there aren't any extras.

The Big Combo is a good example of what some talented people can do with inferior material and a non-existent budget. The brisk pace supplied by director Joseph Lewis and the visually compelling lighting and cinematography work can't hide the fact that the studio put up as much money for this film as they would a tv crime show from the '50's. But oh what a little talent and ingenuity can do for a film. The script is pedestrian and the dialogue is weak except for Richard Conte's dialogue which is usually film noir's strong points. But there are some surprises. First of all the body count is quite high and the filmmakers' push the violence to the breaking point of the Motion Picture Code which kept a watchful eye on all films. But one bit did get through
This is one of the few classic films that was so rough so hard-edged I got rid of it after several viewings....but now wish I had it back. One thing for sure
I'm a fan of the old B&W; detective/mystery films. This one is OK but not great.
You could buy a spiral bound notebook and it would be just as good.

If the intent of this journal was to record our blessings each day then one would need to do some brief hand-scratching to record them in the extremely limited space provided. Perhaps it is based on my beliefs in Buddhist Philosophies but I very much like the idea of giving thanks for five blessings we have received each day. Quite often though I find myself often giving thanks for the same things over and over again
I buy this journal every year and this year I bought one for my niece as well. However when I went to use mine the page saver ribbon was not attached.

I simply love Sarah Ban Breathnach's Simple Abundance. And yes the gratitude journal is a life changing experience. I would recommend it for anyone. This book is also nice if you can sum up your daily gratitude in a few words. I have a few friends who feel 5 lines for 5 daily seeds of gratitude is sufficient.However if you are like me and enjoy journaling. If your 5 items that you are grateful for turns in to 7 10 even 20 items each day (believe me once you get into the habit of the gratitude journal you will become grateful for everything) -- then you need to purchase another journal. I would recommend buying this book for the inspiration but buy a beautiful blank journal later as your gratitude grows!
Expected it to come in a manufactuer package but it came loose in a padded envelope from China. Kind of suprised me.
I bought this for Halloween is very funny see him with this but my baby didn't like it just for take a few picture with also is heavy for a baby mouth.

I bought this because it was a great price and I thought it was a cute gag and perfect for Halloween. It came quickly which was great. The issue I have is the nipple is HUGE and would only work for a much older baby. My baby is going on 6 months and is normal for her size. She can't suck on it it is so big so we can't use it. But it's cheap and cute I just wish they'd be more descriptive on the size.
this product came to me in an envelope - not individually packaged. Cute pacifier - but unsanitarily packaged. this won't go in my grandson's mouth.
Come on Neil why did you spoil this with some of the self-indulgent claptrap you padded it out with?Pros

Juxtapose this with 'Elva' and you nearly have two different bands. 'Here's to the Mourning' takes a step away from 'up all night' and a step toward 'seeing red'. This album is 'Unwritten Law gone So-Cal pop.' On the bright side there are some catchy tunes and a couple of decent but pop-y party songs. On the down side it is not what you'd expect after listening to 'Elva'

Credit veteran SoCal rockers Unwritten Law with putting the sex drugs and rock'n'roll back into punk rock a scene that's been growing progressively straightedge polite and well --bland. The `Law is upholding the immoral fibers that have held true rock'n'roll together while creating dark edgy catchy rock with an ever-present ballsy bravado.Tired of the prepubescent vocals that have plagued punk rock? Fear not `Law frontman Scott Russo's surpassed puberty and developed some of most unmistakable and raspy pipes in music.Guitarists Steve Morris and Rob Brewer's grunge-tinged distorted and power-chord sprinkled strummings compliment Russo's vocals perfectly. Pat Kim provides sinisterly smooth basslines and new drummer Tony Palermo keeps the beat going with ruthless ferocity.With its soaring vocal and instrumental melodies infectious hooks and captivating tempos and guitar effects the `Law's sixth release 'Here's To the Mourning' is arguably their most cohesive and well-rounded offering to date.The first single released from 'Here's To' the soaring anthemic 'Save Me' is already enjoying its top-10 perch atop the alternative chart while its video is enjoying substantial rotation on MTV2 VH-1 and Fuse.'Save Me' isn't the only standout track the album boasts. The soaring sing-a-longs 'Celebration Song' 'Because of You' and 'Walrus' the Prozac frenzied 'Hide Away' the funky 'I Like the Way' the stop-and-go 'She Says' and the hard-nosed tracks 'Get Up' 'Lost Control' and 'Rejections Cold' are all radio-friendly tracks itching for radio airplay.While they may never ride the airways the highly energized and roughly anthemic 'F.I.G.H.T.' and hidden track will beat you over the head steal your wallet and kick the cane out from under your grandfather without a second thought.The `Law had us 'Seein' Red' in 2002. With a new hit single and an addictive album they should be seein' continued success in 2005. Now what they do with the added income is anyone's guess. But if their lyrics are any indicator it'll be something illegal...Sounds Like

The Good'Get Up transfuses heavy riffs meaty bass lines and tuneful vocals that are on the verge of whining. More of that thunderous bass along with catchy rhythms can be heard on 'Celebration Song'. On 'Lost Control' Brewer and Morris whip out some rapid-fire fretwork while Russo proves you can't go wrong with a whoh-whoh chorus in punk song. 'Save Me' is the band's first single which was co-written with Linda Perry (Courtney Love Pink). It starts off with a subtle drum and bass line that leads into driving distorted riffing. The bridge section mixes up the tempo with a brief ska-type rhythm.Unwritten Law mix it up even more with some funky seventies style guitar twang on 'I Like the Way'. Russo's vocals are strong and empowering as he reaches the lively chorus. 'Rejection's Cold' has an infectious opening lick that endures throughout the track. 'F.I.G.H.T.' had to be written with the thought of becoming a high school football anthem. It opens with a riff that's sure to get your blood pumping and the chorus is delivered by a group of cheerleaders; F-I-G-H-T! Be sure to stick around for the impressive bonus track that rounds out the album.The BadNothingThe VerdictIf you have a song co-written by Linda Perry you're not exactly a punk group. However Unwritten Law seem to fit in well with the new pop-punk movement that's taking over the rock radio scene. Here's to the Morning is loaded with plenty of high-energy anthems that never let up.

I've always been a 'meh' fan of Unwritten Law. They've had their songs... not really their cd's though. But I have to say this one is probably their best out of the others. Give it a try but don't be prepared to be blown away or anything.Check out UNDEROATH's newest album... Hellzz yeah.

Average. I've been listening to Russo and the boys for solid for three days after getting my mitts on 'Here's to the Mourning.' It's evident like on 'Elva' that the band has undergone some significant changes since hitting the low-end of 90's mainstream California punk rock. In Elva's footsteps the band (or possibly Russo) sings of depression dissatisfaction and addiction. Walrus' 'Everything gets old / everyone is dumb / so i keep changing / everything is gay everyone is fakeso i can't hang around' has me sadly missing self-titled's careful attention to music feeling and ambiguity. 'Hide Away' has Russo chanting 'slow dance take a chance with me / take off your pants with me' and the music often feels unexplored and void of depth.While chalked full of accurate depictions of Russo's sentiments on life the music is uncomfortably hammered into a poppy radio-friendly version of angst punk making the sound and content uncomfortable for lovers of older UL material.The hooks are there and your foot will tap but you'll quickly tire of the lyrical content Russo's new affinity for F-words to fill gaps his depressive tones and lack of sound variety that even Elva managed to contain. First timers and 'Save Me' radio spin-offs would be better off starting with the self-titled CD or Elva.

In The God Adventure author Terry Meeuwsen (co-host of The 700 Club and Living the Life) invites readers to embark on an adventure of faith. And in embracing this faith adventure Meeuwsen says we can live God's purpose for each of us.Meeuwsen shares her personal story her unique struggles and successes her God adventure in this practical thought-provoking book.When God wants something done He looks for men and women to take the assignment; much like the old television program Mission Impossible. 'Your mission should you choose to accept it is ....' We are offered the opportunities; we just need to decide if we're going to accept His assignment. If we don't someone will. But we'll never know what we've missed! It is an act of faith and not without risk-taking to follow God. But Meeuwsen believes that when we put our own plans on hold wonderful surprises will occur. She calls it a God adventure.This was a timely book for me as I've been on my own 'wilderness journey.' I was able to look back on my own life and clearly see where I stepped out in faith and where I hesitated. After reviewing those experiences it is clear to me that taking the risks believing that God knows what is best for me and will do His best by me has been by far the best part of my journey.After reading this book I can name and claim my experiences as my very own God adventure.

Does anyone have an idea who translated the one published by Classic House Books? This is not a Mirra Ginsburg translation for sure. The name of translator is not mentioned anywhere in the book. I find it to be very shady.

Satan and his cohorts come to Moscow and wreak havoc. People disappear or need urgent psychiatric treatment and as a hostess for satans ball Woland chooses Margarita who willing accepts in order to free and be with the Masteran oppressed author of a novel about Pontius Pilate...Written during Stalins infamous show trials Bulgakov's use of magic realism does invoke the climate of enforced thinking and terrorand in turn satarises the drabness and tedium of soviet life but for me this book just doesn't shine. Its no '1984' or 'Gullivers Travels' and neither does it give the joy of Garcia Marquez's use of the style. Yes I got the idea abour cowardicw being terrors greatest ally and there's plenty of qoutable scenes but you're often left wondering exactly is the point he is making.(The reading of the introduction and annotations are a must to keep the novel alive)The book was written re written and revised many times between 1928 and 1940 and as a result it does seem over egged.
